text:
Abstract
The goal of this work and effort is to protect the religion of Islam from alteration and distortion and from those who attack the religion, because undoubtedly, every call has supporters and opponents. Therefore, I have collected the traditions (Athar) and Hadiths related to Mut'ah marriage - temporary marriage - and studied them through narration (Riwayah) and understanding (Dirayah), clarifying the preponderant ruling, and mentioning the most significant negative effects and consequences resulting from the permissibility of Mut'ah marriage.
The research was divided into three chapters.
Chapter One: The ruling on Mut'ah in Sharia, containing three sections:
a) The history of the permissibility and prohibition of Mut'ah in the Prophetic Sunnah.
b) The Hadiths and Athar reported regarding the prohibition of Mut'ah with a statement of their status regarding acceptance and rejection.
c) The ruling on Mut'ah according to Sunni jurists.
Chapter Two: The ruling on Mut'ah marriage according to the Shi'a, containing three sections:
a) Mentioning the Hadiths they used as evidence for the permissibility of Mut'ah marriage with a statement of their status regarding acceptance and rejection, containing two subsections: First: Discussing the evidences through understanding and narration. Second: Doubts raised about the permissibility of Mut'ah marriage and the answers to them.
b) Mentioning Hadiths prohibiting Mut'ah marriage from Shi'a books and sources.
c) Texts from Shi'a scholars who prohibited Mut'ah marriage.
Chapter Three: The corruptions and effects resulting from the permissibility of Mut'ah marriage, containing three sections:
a) Social effects.
b) Psychological effects.
c) Health effects.
I have not found a book authored on this exact subject, as far as I know, that combined the science of narration and understanding by mentioning the Hadiths and Athar and then what results from permitting it in terms of corruptions and harms to individuals and societies.

text:
Reason for choosing the topic:
When talk about the permissibility of Mut'ah marriage (temporary marriage) became widespread and frequent in some Muslim societies, reaching the point where there is organization and arrangement through publishing photos of women desiring Mut'ah marriage with a contract dowry for a specified term, this topic attracted me. Especially since I did not find a book or author, as far as I know, who combined the science of narration (Riwayah) and understanding (Dirayah) regarding the ruling of Mut'ah marriage while mentioning the corruptions and effects resulting from its permissibility.
Given that my specialization is in the Department of Hadith, I chose the topic of my Master's thesis to be the collection of narratives from news and traditions related to Mut'ah marriage and verifying them along with the jurisprudence of Sunan and Athar, mentioning the evidences of the Shi'a who permit it, discussing them, and citing the sayings of scholars regarding that.
The importance of the research is clarified in the following:
1 - It addresses a dangerous social problem where the feet of some who claim jurisprudence have slipped, as they permitted what Allah Almighty and His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, prohibited of Mut'ah marriage, thus taking a path other than that of the people of verification.
2 - Also among the importance of this topic is that it is a defense of the religion of Islam sent down from the Wise, the Praiseworthy, which falsehood cannot approach from before it or from behind it. It is inappropriate to attribute the permissibility of Mut'ah marriage to the Sharia after the matter was abrogated in the time of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, while Allah Almighty says: {This day I have perfected for you your religion and completed My favor upon you and have approved for you Islam as religion.} [Al-Ma'idah: 3].
3 - Also, regarding this topic, when the reader becomes clear on the correct preponderant ruling of Mut'ah marriage, a certain knowledge arises in him that there is no contradiction or conflict in the religion of Allah.
4 - Among the importance of this topic is appreciating the stance of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, clarifying their virtue, defending them, and not attacking some of the Companions whom the Quran praised and the Most Merciful declared just, and may Allah be pleased with them all.

My Methodology in the Research:
1 - I committed to referring to the Six Books along with Muwatta of Imam Malik, Musnad of Imam Ahmad, and Sunan Al-Darimi. I limited myself to them in mentioning the Hadiths raised (Marfu') to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, only. As for the traditions (Athar) narrated from the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, or the Successors, I mention what I found in some books of Musannafat, Sunan, and Muwatta of Imam Malik, may Allah have mercy on him.
2 - I extracted the Hadiths raised to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, from the Six Books and then judged them, except for the Two Sahihs. As for the traditions narrated from the Companions and Successors, I sufficed with mentioning the author of the tradition along with its source.
3 - I relied on explanations of the Hadiths mostly from the book Fath Al-Bari in explaining Sahih Al-Bukhari, and the explanation of Muslim by Imam Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on both of them.
4 - I committed to referring to books related to the approved Hadiths of the Shi'a, such as Al-Kafi by Al-Kulayni, Al-Istibsar and Tahdhib Al-Ahkam by Al-Tusi, and Wasa'il Al-Shi'a by Al-Hurr Al-Amili mostly, and other books specific to the Shi'a as well.
5 - I also committed not to attribute anything to the Shi'a or to the Sunnis unless I found it truthfully attributed to them, trying to reveal the facts in this subject without fanaticism for a specific opinion or imitation far from the truth.
6 - Finally, I provided biographies for some notable figures I came across as needed by the research, such as biographies of some Shi'a scholars and authors. As for the biography of every scholar, this might distract the reader from the main topic, so their place is in books of history and biographies.

Explanation of the Thesis Title
[Hadiths and Athar Reported Regarding Temporary Marriage: Narration and Understanding]
1 - Al-Ahadith (Hadiths): Plural of Hadith, which linguistically means: opposite of old. Terminologically: What is attributed to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, of speech, action, approval, or description, even movements and rests in wakefulness and sleep; it is more general than Sunnah (1).
2 - Al-Athar (Traditions): Plural of Athar. Linguistically: The remnant. Terminologically: Hadiths, whether raised (Marfu') or suspended (Mawquf) (2).
3 - Al-Nikah (Marriage): Linguistically: The verbal noun of Nakaha. It is said 'Nakaha yankihu' the man and the woman 'Nikahan': from the pattern of 'daraba'. Ibn Faris and others said: It applies to intercourse and to the contract without intercourse. It is said: The woman was married (nukihat): she got married.
Terminologically: Jurists differed in defining Nikah.
The Hanafis said: Nikah is a contract that signifies ownership of enjoyment (Mut'ah) with a female intentionally; meaning it signifies the lawfulness of a man's enjoyment of a woman whose marriage is not prevented by a legal impediment (3).
The Malikis said: Nikah is a contract for the lawfulness of enjoying a female who is not prohibited, a Magian, or a slave, by a formula (4).

Section One
Definition of Mut'ah Marriage
Definition of Mut'ah marriage linguistically and terminologically

A - Mut'ah marriage linguistically:
Ibn Faris said: The Meem, Ta, and Ain are a sound root indicating benefit and extension of a period in goodness. From it is 'istamta'tu' (I enjoyed/benefited) from the thing. Mut'ah and Mata' mean benefit, as in the Almighty's saying: {uninhabited houses in which there is benefit [mata'] for you} [An-Nur: Verse 29]. The divorced woman is given Mut'ah (provision) with something because she benefits from it. It is said 'amta'tu' with my wealth, meaning I benefitted/enjoyed. He said:
Two partners from two tribes until they passed... a long time, and separation was better/extended (amta'a).
Al-Asma'i narrated it: "Bi-tafarruqi" (with separation). He says: The enjoyment of one of them for his companion was nothing but separation.
They say: If you buy this servant boy, you will surely benefit from him as a good servant.
They say: A 'mati'' rope: good, meaning the duration extends with it.
They say: The day 'mata'a': became long. And the plant 'mata'a' mutuan.
The people of verification held that the origin in this chapter is pleasure (Taladh-dhudh). The day 'mata'a' because one enjoys its light. And 'mutti'a' the dust is likened to the enjoyment of the day. And 'Mata'' is benefiting from what has immediate pleasure.
Others held that the origin is extension and elevation, and 'Mata'' is benefit with extended time. A 'mati'' drink: red, meaning it is enjoyed due to its quality (1).
Al-Azhari said: 'Muta'' is the plural of Mut'ah. Al-Layth said: Some of them say 'Mit'ah', and its plural is 'Mita''. Amr narrated from his father that he said: Mut'ah is a little provision, and its plural is Muta'.
foot_note: 1. Mu'jam Maqayis Al-Lughah by Ibn Faris (5/293).

I said: Likewise is the saying of Allah Almighty, the Mighty and Majestic, regarding right guidance {And he who believed said, "O my people, follow me, I will guide you to the way of right conduct (38) O my people, this worldly life is only [temporary] enjoyment, and indeed, the Hereafter - that is the home of [permanent] settlement} [Ghafir: 38-39], meaning: a sufficiency one reaches with, having no permanence. He said: There is no one who separates from his companion but that he provides him (amta'ahu) with something to remember him by, and what each of these two provided the other was that he separated from him.
And the saying of Allah Almighty {so you enjoyed your portion} [At-Tawbah: 69], Al-Farra' said: 'Istamta'u' says: they were content with their share of this world instead of their shares in the Hereafter, and you did as they did. Al-Zajjaj said something similar. Others said: It means: You enjoyed your share of the Hereafter in this world. Al-Mazini recited this verse:
And from us on the morning of terror are youths of courage... If the fingers are extended (umti'at) after the palms (1).

B - Mut'ah marriage terminologically according to Sunni Jurists:
Al-Qurtubi - may Allah Almighty have mercy on him - said about Mut'ah marriage: It is "that a man marries a woman with two witnesses, and the permission of the guardian, for a specified term, and on the condition that there is no inheritance between them, and he gives her what they agreed upon. If the period expires, he has no way over her, and she clears her womb (waits to ensure no pregnancy). If she is not pregnant, she becomes lawful for others" (2).
The Kuwaiti Fiqh Encyclopedia mentioned the definition of Mut'ah terminologically: It is the contract with a woman for a known or unknown period (3).

text:
Section Two
Usages of the term Mut'ah in Sharia
Al-Katib Al-Balkhi Al-Khwarizmi mentioned the meaning of Mut'ah according to jurists in three ways:
First: That a man marries a woman for a small dowry for a known period, on the condition that the marriage dissolves upon its expiration without divorce. This is permissible according to the Shi'a.
Second: The clothing of a divorced woman if she is divorced before consummation.
Third: Mut'ah of Hajj, which is that one performs Tamattu' (enjoyment) when he finishes his circumambulation, and what was prohibited becomes lawful for him (1).
Mut'ah is a noun from Tamattu', and from it comes Mut'ah of Hajj, Mut'ah of Divorce, and Mut'ah Marriage.
In terminology, Tamattu' is used for two meanings:
First: In the sense of Mut'ah of Nikah, which is the contract with a woman for a known or unknown period. It is void without dispute among the Imams, because the objectives of marriage are not intended by it.
Second: In the sense of Mut'ah by Umrah to Hajj. According to the Hanafis, it is performing the actions of Umrah or most of them in the months of Hajj and performing Hajj in that same year without returning to his family a valid return - and valid return is settling in his homeland without the state of Ihram remaining - and assuming Ihram for Hajj from the Haram (2).
Third: Mut'ah of Divorce. Al-Shirbini Al-Khatib said: Money that a husband must pay to his wife who is separated in life by divorce or what resembles it, with conditions (3).

2. Al-Zayla'i (2/45), and Maraqi Al-Falah with Hashiyat Al-Tahawi (p. 402).

Section Three
The Reality of Mut'ah Marriage and its Conditions according to the Shi'a
The reality of Mut'ah marriage:
This marriage is: A marriage contract between a man and a woman, with a specific dowry mentioned in the text of the contract, for a specific term. Upon the arrival of the term, or by the husband gifting the period to her, the marriage bond dissolves without the need for divorce. The woman says: "I married you, or wedded you, or gave myself to you in Mut'ah for a dowry of such amount for a period of a month or a year or less or more." The man says to her: "I accept." So the marital status is established until the end of the specified period, or until he gifts her the remaining period.
After the period ends, she observes Iddah (waiting period) - like a female slave - for two menstrual cycles. It is said: one cycle, if she is of those who menstruate. And for forty-five days if she does not menstruate while being of menstruating age. The Iddah of a pregnant woman and one whose husband has died is like the Iddah of a permanent wife.
All legal conditions must be met in this marriage, including puberty, sanity, choice... etc., with the absence of any legal impediment such as: lineage, cause (marriage relation), breastfeeding, being currently married (Ihsan), being in Iddah for another, or her being the sister of a wife, or similar things. This is in addition to the availability of other conditions of permanent marriage, as established in jurisprudential books.
The child of Mut'ah belongs to his father and inherits from him like all his other children, and all general legal rulings regarding fathers, mothers, brothers, sisters, paternal aunts, maternal aunts... etc. apply to him (1).

text:
Ali bin Babawayh Al-Qummi (1) said: Mut'ah marriage is a marriage without witnesses or inheritance. It is that the woman is asked: Is she free or occupied with a husband or Iddah or pregnancy? If she is free from that, he says to her: 'Provide me enjoyment of yourself upon the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace be upon him and his family, a marriage not fornication, such and such for such and such.' You state the dowry and the term, on the condition that you do not inherit from me nor I from you, and that I place the water (semen) wherever I wish, and that when the term expires, you observe an Iddah of forty-five days. If she agrees, you say to her: 'You have provided me enjoyment of yourself' and repeat all conditions to her, because the first saying, and every condition before the marriage, is void, and the matter is only contracted by the second saying. If she says 'Yes' in the second instance, he pays her the dowry or what is present of it, and what remains is a debt upon you, and her intercourse becomes lawful for you then (2).
Abu Salah Al-Halabi (3) said: As for Mut'ah marriage, two things are conditions for its validity: specifying the wage and the term. If the wage is mentioned but the term is not, it becomes permanent. If the term is mentioned without the wage, the contract is void. Its description is that the one desiring it says to the one he wants to enjoy - and whose guardianship over herself and contracting upon her is valid due to her puberty, perfect sanity, and freedom from husband, Iddah, and pregnancy: 'I want you to provide me enjoyment of yourself upon the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace be upon him and his family, for such and such days or months or years for such and such dirhams or dinars or whatever has value, on the condition that you do not inherit from me nor I from you, and that I place the water wherever I wish, and you have no housing or maintenance, and upon you is the Iddah when the period expires.' If she agrees, he says to her: 'Provide me enjoyment of yourself upon the Book of Allah Almighty and the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace be upon him and his family, such and such for such and such with the mentioned conditions.' When he finishes his saying, she should say: 'I have accepted and agreed.' It is better if she says: 'I have provided you enjoyment of myself such and such for such and such,' and mentions the conditions, and he accepts from her. If this marriage is contracted, the Mut'ah husband must pay the entire wage, and delaying part of it with her consent is permissible.

text:
Section Four
Objectives of Islam in Legislating Marriage
Marriage in Islamic Sharia has great purposes and virtues, as stated in the Holy Quran, including:
(1 - Affection, Mercy, and Tranquility. The Almighty said: {And of His signs is that He created for you from yourselves mates that you may find tranquility in them; and He placed between you affection and mercy} [Ar-Rum: Verse 21]. And He said: {It is He who created you from one soul and created from it its mate that he might dwell in security with her. And when he covers her, she carries a light burden and continues therein. And when it becomes heavy, they both invoke Allah, their Lord, "If You should give us a good [child], we will surely be among the grateful."} [Al-A'raf: Verse 189]. These verses indicated the most important goals and objectives of legislating marriage in Islam, including forming the righteous family which constitutes the first nucleus of Islamic society, with its intrinsic characteristics of chastity and purity. This is the secret behind Islam's entire keenness on protecting the Muslim family with an impregnable fence to achieve the goals and objectives for which its rulings were legislated. Thus, it can be said that the permanent wife is the one whom Allah's Sunnah made a tranquility for the man. The Holy Quran indicated that this tranquility and psychological and cardiac reassurance are under the shade of correct permanent marriage; that is Allah's Sunnah in His creation. Perhaps making (Tranquility), (Affection), and (Mercy) a requirement leads to that good fruit which the human soul aspires to by virtue of its nature and instinct. From this, it is known that the basic goal and objective of marriage is not limited to satisfying lust; rather, the intent is the formation of the family whose detailed rulings were legislated by the Holy Quran - from engagement, to marriage, to divorce if the spouses do not agree and cannot establish Allah's limits, then rulings of breastfeeding and maintenance, all to achieve social solidarity) (1).

Section One
History of the permissibility of Mut'ah marriage and its prohibition in the Prophetic Sunnah
[Sunni jurists do not deny that Mut'ah was permitted in some necessary occasions in the era of the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him. One who tracks the hadiths of Mut'ah's permissibility in the beginning sees that this permission was not while settled in the homeland and house, but rather it was permitted in distant raids and long travel; when lust intensifies, patience decreases, and trial and weakness of chastity are feared. It was wise that their weaning from immorality be gradual, just as alcohol was prohibited. (Mut'ah marriage was permitted when it was permitted for necessity in the case of travel, raiding, and distance from homeland and wife; as an honor to the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, who are the ideal generation that sacrificed themselves and their wealth in the path of Allah, bearing the most expensive sacrifices and gravest hardships. When the reasons for permissibility vanished and souls were gradually weaned from their accustomed habits in that transitional stage from Jahiliyyah to Islam, and the Islamic society took its path to stability, and legislation turned to perfecting the final form of basic rulings, Allah permitted His Prophet to prohibit Mut'ah and abrogate it forever)] (1).
Imam Al-Nawawi quoted in his explanation of "Sahih Muslim" from Qadi Iyad saying: "Hadiths of Mut'ah were narrated by a group of Companions... And in none of these Hadiths was it in residence (*Hadar*), but rather it was in their travels in raids, at their necessity, and lack of women, considering their lands were hot and their patience from them little. It was mentioned in the Hadith of Ibn Umar that it was a license in the beginning of Islam for one driven to it by necessity like carrion and the like..." (2).

Hadiths and Athar Reported Regarding the Prohibition of Mut'ah Marriage with a Statement of Their Status Regarding Acceptance and Rejection
The text regarding the prohibition of Mut'ah marriage came from seven Companions, namely:

The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, saw lamps and women weeping. He said: "What is this?" It was said: Women weeping who were enjoyed (Mut'ah). Peace and blessings be upon him said: "Mut'ah has been prohibited - or he said: demolished - Marriage, Divorce, Iddah, and Inheritance." Narrated by Abu Ya'la. Section Three
Ruling on Mut'ah According to Sunni Jurists
Sunni jurists view that Mut'ah marriage was permitted due to compelling necessity for days in time, in cases of long travel and distant raids in the early days of Islam when Muslims were new to leaving Jahiliyyah. Then it was prohibited decisively and eternally, after the pillar of religion straightened, the strength of believers increased, and their faith and commitment hardened, becoming in no need of seeking such licenses (1).
Sunni jurists inferred the correctness of their school with evidences from the Quran and the Noble Prophetic Sunnah, as well as Consensus (Ijma') and sound Reason. Following are the evidences they used:

Evidences of Sunni Jurists from the Holy Quran and Noble Prophetic Sunnah:
First: The Holy Quran:
Allah Almighty said: {And they who guard their private parts (5) Except from their wives or those their right hands possess, for indeed, they will not be blamed (6) But whoever seeks beyond that, then those are the transgressors} [Al-Mu'minun: 5-7].
Point of Inference: The verses clarified the types of permissible marriages in Islam, restricted to correct permanent marriage and right-hand possession (slaves), and prohibited what is below that. Imam of exegetes Ibn Jarir Al-Tabari says: "Whoever seeks for his private part a marriage other than his wife or right hand possession, the doers of that are the transgressors, who exceeded what Allah permitted for them to what He prohibited for them, so they are the blamed ones" (2).
Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi mentioned in Tarikh Baghdad a stance of Judge Yahya bin Aktham. He said: We were with Al-Ma'mun on the way to Sham. He ordered a crier to announce the permissibility of Mut'ah. Yahya bin Aktham said to us: Go early

Third: Inference by Consensus (Ijma'):
The majority of Companions went to the prohibition of Mut'ah marriage, due to the Prophet's prohibition of it, peace and blessings be upon him, and his prohibiting it eternally. Then Consensus was convened in the time of Commander of the Faithful Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, when he forbade it after news reached him that some men practiced Mut'ah in his days. He reminded them from the pulpit of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, of the ruling of prohibition, and the Companions approved him in that (1).
Qadi Iyad said: Scholars agreed that this Mut'ah was permissible for a term with no inheritance, and separation occurs by expiration of the term without divorce. Then Consensus occurred after that on its prohibition by all scholars (2).
Al-Qurtubi said: All narrations agree that the time of Mut'ah's permissibility did not last long and that it became prohibited. Then the Salaf and Khalaf (Predecessors and Successors) agreed on its prohibition except those who are not paid attention to. A group of Imams asserted Ibn Abbas's solitude in permitting it. It is a famous issue, and the opponent is rare. However, Ibn Abd al-Barr said: The companions of Ibn Abbas from the people of Mecca and Yemen held its permissibility, then the jurists of the regions agreed on its prohibition (3).
Al-Jassas said: We have indicated the establishment of prohibition after permission from the apparent meaning of the Book and Sunnah and consensus of the Salaf. Abu Bakr said: We have mentioned regarding Mut'ah and its ruling of prohibition what is sufficient for one who advises himself. There is no disagreement about it among the first generation as we explained. The jurists of the regions agreed with that on its prohibition and do not differ on it. Jurists differed regarding one who marries a woman for known days. Abu Hanifa, Abu Yusuf, Muhammad, Malik bin Anas, Al-Thawri, Al-Awza'i, and Al-Shafi'i said: If he marries a woman for ten days, it is void and there is no marriage between them (4).

text:
Subsection One
Discussing Shi'a Evidences Used for Permissibility of Mut'ah Marriage through Understanding and Narration

First: Discussion through Understanding (Dirayah):
[Their inference with His saying Almighty {So for whatever you enjoy [of marriage] from them, give them their due compensation as an obligation. And there is no blame upon you for what you mutually agree to beyond the obligation} [An-Nisa: 29] as came in the hadith of Abu Ja'far narrated by Sheikh Al-Kulayni in Al-Kafi. The verse implies the linguistic meaning of 'Istimta'' which is pleasure and benefit. The meaning is (So whatever you benefited and enjoyed of intercourse from women by correct marriage) i.e., by its contract. What necessitates this implication is several matters:
1 - What is mentioned at the beginning and end of the verses is Marriage (Nikah); it moves us from one ruling in marriage to another ruling in it. The verses are focused on clarifying the ruling of correct marriage, and Mut'ah has no mention in them.
2 - There is a difference between saying (So-and-so married Mut'ah yesterday, and so-and-so enjoyed [istamta'a] marriage). The first refers to temporary marriage, unlike the second which implies nothing but the meaning of benefit and pleasure in known marriage, and the verse structure is of the second type, indicating pleasure.
3 - Since the word is intended to mean pleasure, something must be implied after it, lest the apparent meaning of the verse implies that anyone who enjoys a woman and gives her wage is permitted to do so, which is impermissible by consensus. Thus, the word (contract) must be implied, which permits pleasure and intercourse, and we attributed the contract to known marriage due to agreement on the correctness of this implication] (1).
Also it is said: Allah Almighty did not express in this noble verse using the verbal noun (Istimta') nor the noun (Mut'ah). He did not say, for example, "So whatever you married by Mut'ah", otherwise there would be no disagreement. But

He expressed it with the verb form, saying: (FAMAA ISTAMTA'TUM - So whatever you enjoyed). The difference between them is clear. The verb's meaning revolves around pleasure and benefit, as in language books. Imams of language declared that the verb (istamta'a) in this place has no meaning except what we mentioned. The word (istamta'a) appeared in other than this place and did not mean Mut'ah by agreement, as in His saying Glory be to Him {You exhausted your good things in your worldly life and enjoyed [istamta'tum] them} [Al-Ahqaf: 20] meaning you hastened to benefit from them. And He said {so you enjoyed [fastamta'tum] your portion} [At-Tawbah: 69] (meaning you benefited from your luck and share) (1).
Ibn Al-Jawzi said: As for the verse, it did not imply the permissibility of Mut'ah, because He Almighty said in it {seeking with your wealth [marriage], being chaste, not unlawful fornicators}. This indicates correct marriage (2). Enjoyment (Tamattu') does not necessitate Ihsan (being fortified/chaste) according to permissors, since they do not require stoning for one who commits Zina after Mut'ah. Stoning only applies to one who married permanently. Allah Almighty only permitted seeking with wealth what necessitates Ihsan (3).
Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said: As for Mut'ah of women which is disputed, there is no explicit text in the verse for its permissibility. For He Almighty said: {And lawful to you are [all others] beyond these, [provided] that you seek them [in marriage] with your property, desiring chastity, not unlawful sexual intercourse. So for whatever you enjoy [of marriage] from them, give them their due compensation as an obligation. And there is no blame upon you for what you mutually agree to beyond the obligation. Indeed, Allah is ever Knowing and Wise (24) And whoever among you cannot [find] the means to marry free, believing women} [An-Nisa: 24-25]. His saying: (So for whatever you enjoy from them) covers everyone with whom marriage is consummated, for he is ordered to be given the full dowry, unlike the divorced woman before consummation who was not enjoyed, for she deserves only half of it. This is His saying Almighty: {And how could you take it while you have gone in unto each other and they have taken from you a solemn covenant} [An-Nisa: 21]. So He made consummation with the contract a cause for establishing the dowry. This shows that specializing temporary marriage with giving the wage without permanent marriage has no meaning; rather giving

This is indicated by the fact that He mentioned after this the marriage of slave girls, so it is known that what was mentioned was regarding the marriage of free women absolutely. If it is said: A group of the Salaf read: (So whatever you enjoy from them *to a specified term*), it is said: First: This reading is not Mutawatir, and at most it is like Ahad reports; rather it is of the anomalous (Shadh) readings, and we do not deny that Mut'ah was permitted in early Islam, but the speech is about the indication of the Quran on that. Second: It is said: This letter (phrase), if it was revealed, then undoubtedly, it is not established in the famous reading, so it is abrogated. Its revelation would be when Mut'ah was permissible. When prohibited, 'to a specified term' was abrogated. Wage is obligatory if named, and that is if enjoyment to a specified term was lawful. This was in early Islam. There is nothing in the verse indicating that enjoying her to a specified term is lawful, for He did not say: 'And it is permitted for you to enjoy them to a specified term', but said (So whatever you enjoy from them, give them their wages). This covers whatever enjoyment occurred, whether lawful or as in intercourse by mistake (*Wat' Shubha*) (1).

Subsection Two
Doubts Raised About Permissibility of Mut'ah Marriage and Answers to Them

1 - Doubt of Ibn Abbas's Fatwa - may Allah be pleased with them:
The Shi'a argue for their permissibility of Mut'ah with the Fatwa of Ibn Abbas may Allah be pleased with them. The answer to it: Proof is only in the saying of Allah and saying of His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, and no one has a say after the saying of Allah and His Messenger. Allah Almighty says {Follow what has been revealed to you from your Lord} [Al-A'raf: 3]. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Verily I have been given the Book and its like with it) - meaning the Sunnah - (1). So what was revealed to us from our Lord are the two Revelations (Quran and Sunnah), and whoever claims otherwise must provide evidence, and there is no evidence! We do not claim infallibility for Ibn Abbas or anyone else, for infallibility is only for a Prophet {Nor does he speak from [his own] inclination (3) It is not but a revelation revealed} [An-Najm: 3-4]. Some Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, denied it upon him, including:
Ali, may Allah be pleased with him. Muslim extracted in his Sahih from Al-Hasan and Abdullah sons of Muhammad bin Ali from their father from Ali may Allah be pleased with him that he heard Ibn Abbas being lenient regarding Mut'ah of women. He said: (Gently, O Ibn Abbas) (2). Ali said to him: You are a lost man - for the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade it on the day of Khaybar and meat of domestic donkeys) [Narrated by the Two Sheikhs: Bukhari and Muslim].
And Ibn Umar: From Salim bin Abdullah said: Abdullah bin Umar was approached and told Ibn Abbas commands Mut'ah marriage. Ibn Umar said: Glory be to Allah! I don't think Ibn Abbas does this. They said: Yes he commands it. He said: Was Ibn Abbas anything but a small boy? When the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was alive. Then Ibn Umar said: (The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade us from it,

Furthermore, Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, did not see permissibility of Mut'ah absolutely as Shi'a spread. Sheikh Al-Ahdal says: What is famous from Ibn Abbas is his license in it for the compelled/distressed (*Mudtarr*), not absolutely. Despite this, it was not conceded to him; Ali, Ibn Umar, Ibn Al-Zubayr, Ibn Abi Amrah and others criticized him, and he retracted this saying (2).
The evidence that Ibn Abbas only permitted it for the compelled is the Hadith narrated by Imam Al-Bukhari from Abu Jamra who said: I heard Ibn Abbas being asked about Mut'ah of women, and he permitted it. A client (Mawla) of his said to him: That is only in severe condition and scarcity of women or similar. Ibn Abbas said: Yes (3).
Al-Bayhaqi has via Al-Ismaili: (That was only in Jihad and women were few. Ibn Abbas said: True) [Al-Sunan Al-Kubra by Al-Bayhaqi (7/204)]. What supports that Mut'ah was in severe condition and few women is what the Two Sheikhs extracted from Ibn Masud may Allah be pleased with him said: (We used to raid with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, having no women. We said: Shall we not castrate ourselves? He forbade us from that, then permitted us to marry a woman for a garment for a term) (4).
Imam Al-Hazimi may Allah have mercy on him said: (As for what is recounted from Ibn Abbas, he was interpreting its permissibility for those compelled to it due to long celibacy and lack of wealth and capability, then he stopped and withheld fatwa on it) (5).

The Shi'a argue with the Hadith of the noble Companion Imran bin Husayn may Allah be pleased with him which confused many. He said may Allah be pleased with him: (The Verse of Mut'ah was revealed in the Book of Allah, so we did it with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and no Quran was revealed prohibiting it, nor did he forbid it until he died. Texts of Shi'a Scholars Who Prohibited Mut'ah Marriage

1 - Establishing a committee dedicated to studying Shia books and sources, in terms of accepting what is authentic from them and rejecting what is false, so that Muslims unite on one ruling, which is taking from everything authentic from our Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him).
2 - Encouraging our professors in the Faculty of Islamic Sharia, and some students in graduate studies who specialize, especially in the sciences of the Noble Hadith, to proceed with studying the authentication of Sunnah according to the Shia sect, as an extensive study to obtain Master's and Ph.D. degrees.
3 - Providing a special library that includes all Shia books, to facilitate for students and specialized researchers to review them and then judge them.
Finally, I ask Allah Almighty that this thesis be purely for His Noble Face, beneficial to Islam and Muslims. If I have succeeded in it to the truth, then this is from the bounty of the All-Knowing, the Wise, and if I erred, then this is from me and from Satan, and I seek forgiveness from Allah the Almighty, the Great. And may Allah bless our Prophet Muhammad and all his family and companions.
